Mongolia: Promoting Inclusive Growth 
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction)

members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) is included in the 2012–2014 country operations business 
plan for Mongolia.1 A fact-finding mission visited Ulaanbaatar in March 2012 and agreement 
was reached with the government on the TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, costs and financing, 
implementation  arrangements,  and  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services.  The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Mongolia’s economic outlook is bright, but there is a risk that the focus on development 
of the mining sector will lead to neglect of other parts of the economy and result in greater 
disparities  in  income  and  access  to  basic  services.  Rapid  economic  growth  has  been 
accompanied by falling poverty rates, but there is growing realization among stakeholders in the 
country that (i) inequality is rising; (ii) job creation is critical for addressing inequality; and (iii) 
there is a need to raise awareness and understanding, and strengthen policy formulation to 
ensure inclusive growth in Mongolia. 
 
3.  Despite high overall economic growth rates in many Asian countries since the 1990s, 
many  policy  makers  in  Asia  and  in  international  organizations  have  become  increasingly 
concerned that this growth has been too uneven and often accompanied by rising income 
inequality. Disadvantaged groups, including members of ethnic minorities, people in remote 
rural  locations,  and  women,  have  not  benefited  proportionately  from  rapid  economic 
advancement.3 The realization that the process of growth often leaves poor and disadvantaged 
people behind is becoming increasingly relevant in political debates and in economic and social 
policy formulation. 
 
4.  Growth in Mongolia is expected to continue to be strong in 2012 and beyond, supported 
by high global mineral prices, development of new mines, and fiscal spending. Fiscal policy is 
expected  to  be  expansionary  in  the  coming  years,  increasing  inflationary  pressures  and 
crowding out non-mineral industries. Evidence shows that resource dependence often leads to 
economic inequality, as resource extraction creates relatively few jobs, while commodity rents 
accrue to a relatively small portion of the population. High inequality may, in turn, negatively 
affect development prospects as many talented people have little or no access to education and 
capital. High inequality may also undermine social cohesion and result in social unrest. 
 
5.  Protecting  people  with  low  skills  and  income  from  the  impact  of  high  inflation  and 
enabling their full participation in economic growth through greater employment and access to 
core public services is a key government responsibility. Strategy 2020 identifies inclusive growth 
as one of ADB’s three strategic pillars along with environmental sustainability and regional 
integration. It emphasizes the need to promote a development strategy which (i) provides 
greater  access  to  opportunities  by  expanding  human  capacities  through  investments  in 
education, health, and basic social protection; (ii) improves the poor’s access to markets and 
basic productive assets by putting in place sound policies and institutions; and (iii) strengthens

social  safety  nets.4 The  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development  further 
supports  the  thrust  of  ADB’s  Strategy  2020  by  advocating  a  policy  approach  to  reducing 
inequality based on three pillars: human capital investment, inclusive employment promotion, 
and well-designed redistribution policies.5 There is a need to analyze constraints to inclusive 
growth in Mongolia, with emphasis on the non-resource sectors.6 Given the changes in the 
economy and the resulting rapid socioeconomic changes, there is also a need to refocus 
broader  development  objectives  and  prioritize  inclusiveness  in  development  planning  and 
policies. This necessitates consensus and capacity building at the national and local levels and 
the development of clear road maps for policies and programs.  
 
6.  To support inclusive growth, the government is supporting inclusion by strengthening 
vocational  training,  increasing  social  security  coverage,  promoting  employment  for 
disadvantaged  groups,  and  investing  in  disadvantaged  urban  areas.  These  need  to  be 
complemented by policy development capacity and a long-term strategy focused on achieving 
inclusive  growth  to  (i) create  and  expand  economic  opportunities  (mainly  productive 
employment); and (ii) ensure broader access to these opportunities for members of society to 
participate in and benefit from growth (footnote 4). Currently, there is limited public debate and 
understanding of the consequences of social and economic inequality; no monitoring and a lack 
of capacity across various sectors (government, private sector, media, civil society) to define 
and monitor progress toward inclusive growth; and weak policy and development capacity to be 
able to address inclusive growth in key sectors. Identifying and addressing such constraints will 
support inclusive growth and good governance.  
 
7.  Since 2009, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), in cooperation with Japan International 
Cooperation Agency and the World Bank, has supported modernization of the social welfare 
system  in  Mongolia  by  improving  targeting  methodologies  and  introducing  social  transfers 
directly targeted at the poor.7 As a second step, poor and marginalized households need to be 
brought into the formal labor market to obtain decent and productive jobs to sustain their living 
standards. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  that  Mongolia’s  medium-term  strategic  plan  and  the 
corresponding yearly socioeconomic development guidelines reflect inclusive growth policies. 
The outcome will be the improved capacity to develop policies on inclusive growth among key 
public and private stakeholders. The overall objective of the TA is to promote inclusive growth 
strategies in selected socioeconomic sectors of Mongolia.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  To increase the capacity to develop policies on inclusive growth among key public and 
private stakeholders, the TA will (i) identify the main drivers of inequality and constraints to more 
inclusiveness in Mongolia, (ii) conduct a consultative process to identify key constraints to 
inclusive growth involving key public and private stakeholders to support these efforts, (iii) 
improve  institutional  and  human  capacity  for  inclusive  growth  in  selected  government  and 
professional business entities, and (iv) provide policy recommendations on inclusive growth and 
future project investments in priority areas.  
 
10.  Key activities of the TA will be organized under four outputs:  
(i)  Output 1: Analysis of inclusiveness of growth. Analytical work under this 
output will focus on identifying the key drivers of inequality. This analysis will 
directly  lead  to  recommendations  for  policy  reforms  and  programmatic 
interventions  for  key  sectors  under  output  4.  A  priority  area  will  be  critical 
analysis of existing labor market mechanisms and their capacity to fully engage 
the private sector and match supply to demand. 
(ii)  Output 2: Consultative process for inclusiveness of growth. These activities 
will engage the public and a wide range of stakeholders in a participatory process 
to identify key constraints to inclusiveness of growth in Mongolia. Pre- and post-
surveys  will  be  implemented  to  determine  changes  in  capacity  to  develop 
inclusive growth policies. Awareness and capacity building activities such as 
hosting  debates  with  international  experts  and  creating  capacity  building 
materials  and  tools  will  ensure  that  understanding  of  concepts  particularly 
significant for Mongolia and experience of other countries are shared with the 
government, private sector, and civil society stakeholders. 
(iii)  Output 3: Institutional and human capacity development. Activities under this 
output  will  address  capacity  issues  and  develop  tools  for  a  broad  range  of 
stakeholders in selected government and professional business entities at the 
national as well as the local level. This includes institutional development for the 
Cabinet Office, the Ministry of Finance (MOF), and the Ministry of Economic 
Development  (MED)  on  mechanisms  and  indicators  for  monitoring  inclusive 
growth in government monitoring systems. It also includes activities to increase 
policy makers’ and business community members’ capacity for policy analysis, 
identifying  constraints  to  and  addressing  inclusiveness.  The  capacity 
development activities will help participants to develop policies and plans, and 
implement and monitor specific programs focusing on inclusive growth. A pilot 
project to support decentralized procurement through capacity building will be 
conducted under this output in collaboration with Japan International Cooperation 
Agency and the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation.8 The pilot 
project will build on two important legal initiatives of the government in 2011 that 
will support inclusive growth: (i) the law on integrated budget that promotes the 
                                                 
8  The collaboration will be implemented as follows: (i) the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation will 
support decentralization of the budget authority by providing capacity building activities to local government and 
civil society in budgeting, planning, and prioritization; (ii) ADB will provide capacity building to small and medium-
sized enterprises, local government, and civil society in procurement processes; and (iii) Japan International 
Cooperation Agency will assist the MOF in establishing audit units to supervise the decentralization process. The 
combined support will improve the use of decentralized budgets, stimulate the local economy, and create jobs. The 
output will be actionable recommendations to the Procurement Policy Division of the MOF on how to support 
decentralized procurement, including oversight by civil society.

4   
decentralization of budget authority, and (ii) the amended law on procurement 
that promotes local procurement. The amended procurement law (effective in 
October 2012) calls for services and materials for local government development 
and investment programs to begin to be procured from local small and medium-
sized enterprises. The intention is to facilitate local development and develop 
skills  among  local  service  providers—supporting  economic  growth  in  areas 
beyond major urban centers and large service providers.  
(iv)  Output  4:  Policy  and  inclusiveness  of  growth  investment  strategy 
development.  Activities  under  this  output  will  contribute  to  inclusive  policy 
development in key sectors and identify potential project investments to promote 
inclusive growth. Policy formulation will rest on the analysis of inclusiveness of 
growth (output 1), the results of the consultative process (output 2), and specific 
activities under output 4. To assist in policy formulation, the TA will explore best 
international policy practices for inclusive growth from resource-rich countries, 
study corporate social responsibility practices, and implement a pilot project to 
increase access to employment for urban and rural poor households that have 
been identified by the national proxy means test.9 Lessons from the TA will be 
captured in a knowledge product on promoting inclusiveness in growth that will 
identify  the  drivers  and  policy  recommendations  and  propose  investment 
programs and strategies in priority sectors to support inclusive growth.10 The pilot 
project will be conducted in collaboration with Japan International Cooperation 
Agency and will build on the passage of the labor enhancement law in 2011, 
which includes a provision for providing government subsidies to companies that 
employ  poor  households.  This  will  help  create  a  surer  path  and  more 
opportunities for the poor to be able to transfer from being recipients of welfare 
payments to being employed in the formal sector.11 
 
11.  Government support to promote inclusive growth is strong; it is assumed that public 
support will continue and private sector stakeholders will be engaged in developing policies on 
inclusive growth. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The Government of 
Mongolia will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, remuneration 
and per diem of counterpart staff, and administrative support.  
 
                                                 
9 The ADB-funded Food and Nutrition Social Welfare Program and Project has supported implementation of a 
national proxy means test to identify poor households. The resulting database is being used to target social welfare 
programs such as the food stamp and medicard programs (supported by ADB). It is expected that the database will 
eventually support targeting of other programs such as education or energy subsidies or access to employment 
and skills building programs. 
10 Potential investments to promote inclusive growth include improvement of water and sanitation in ger (traditional 
tent) areas of Ulaanbaatar, expansion of power and heating supply systems, access to finance, business support 
systems, development of the hospitality infrastructure in poorer areas of Mongolia, and expansion of the school 
and hospital systems. 
11 The collaboration will be implemented as follows: (i) ADB will carry out an analysis of the local labor market and 
assess the effectiveness of local employment services; and (ii) Japan International Cooperation Agency will 
provide a Japan overseas cooperation volunteer who will be involved in the daily implementation of the pilot project 
by contacting poor households (identified through proxy means testing), assessing their skills, providing information 
to employment services and potential employers, and documenting the pilot project.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Department of Development Financing and Cooperation of the MOF will be the 
executing  agency,  and  the  Department  of  Development  Policy,  Strategic  Planning  and 
Coordination of the MED will be the implementing agency for the TA.  
14.  The  MOF  prepares  Mongolia’s  yearly  socioeconomic  guidelines  and  the  MED  is 
institutionally responsible for preparing the medium-term strategic development plan. Hence, the 
MOF and the MED will be crucial in ensuring socioeconomic guidelines, and planning will reflect 
inclusive growth policies. Implementation of the TA will also involve the Mongolian National 
Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which plays a vital role in creating links between the 
private sector (especially small and medium-sized enterprises) and employment seekers. It will 
help in engaging business entities in inclusive growth discussions, capacity building, and policy 
formulation. 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 27 months from March 2013 to May 2015. ADB will 
recruit a consulting firm using quality- and cost-based selection with the standard ratio of 80:20 
to provide 16 person-months of international and 64 person-months of national consultants, 
including  expertise  in  (i)  socioeconomic  analysis  and  policy  development,  (ii) consultative 
processes and outreach, and (iii) the development and implementation of social surveys. The 
firm will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). An administrative and technical coordinator will be recruited as an 
individual consultant to facilitate day-to-day organizational and technical matters and liaise with 
the executing agency. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. The 
executing agency will be responsible for procurement of the TA equipment in accordance with 
ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  will  retain  the 
equipment upon TA completion. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). A country 
diagnostic study is being planned by the Mongolia Resident Mission and the Economic Analysis 
and Operations Support Division of ADB’s Economics and Research Department. The study 
(currently  planned  for  2014–2015)  will  analyze  (i)  the  binding  constraints  to  growth  and 
associated policy priorities, and (ii) the critical constraints to inclusiveness of growth. The focus 
of  this  TA  is  on  the  inclusiveness  aspects.  The  TA  activities  and  knowledge  product  will 
complement  the  country  diagnostic  study  by  providing  clear  sectoral  recommendations  to 
promote equal opportunities to employment and project investments to support inclusiveness of 
growth.  
16.  The TA will undertake a participatory process to understand key constraints to the 
inclusiveness of growth in Mongolia and ensure wide dissemination of the results among the 
key stakeholders in the government and private sector through a series of seminars. The TA will 
also  support  the  government’s  efforts  for  wider  awareness  building  and  information 
dissemination. In this regard, two high-profile workshops with international experts on inclusive 
growth will also be organized. The TA will prepare a knowledge product on inclusive growth in 
Mongolia, including drivers of inequality, inclusive policy recommendations in key sectors, and 
proposed investment programs in priority sectors; the results will be disseminated through a 
conference and printed material. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction for Promoting Inclusive Growth, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A  consulting  firm  will  be  recruited  using  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  with  the 
standard ratio of 80:20 to provide the following consultants. Implementation of activities requires 
prior approval of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
 
A.  Socioeconomic Analysis and Policy Development 
   
2.  Senior social and economic policy development expert—team leader (international, 
11 person-months).1 The expert will preferably have at least 15 years of experience in areas of 
inclusive growth and policy analysis, with at least a master’s degree in development economics 
or other relevant sectors. The expert will work with and directly report to the ADB task manager. 
The expert will 
(i)  plan  and  organize  a  participatory  process  to  define  inclusive  growth  in  the 
context of Mongolia, and disseminate its results; 
(ii)  identify,  manage,  and  compensate  an  eminent  international  speaker  and  a 
national  speaker  to  participate  in  the  dissemination  of  the  results  of  the 
participatory assessment; 
(iii)  plan, organize, and carry out two high profile international workshops on inclusive 
growth, including identifying, inviting, managing, and compensating an eminent 
speaker for each of the debates; 
(iv)  prepare tools to disseminate information, create awareness for inclusive growth, 
and identify, invite, manage, and compensate six national speakers in carrying 
out the outreach campaign for the consultative process on inclusive growth; 
(v)  develop  monitoring  and  evaluation  and  policy  analysis  capacity  for  inclusive 
growth  of  the  Cabinet  Office,  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  Ministry  of  Economic 
Development, and selected sector ministries (Ministry of Population Development 
and Social Protection, Ministry of Health, and Ministry of Education and Science); 
(vi)  develop capacity development tools for action on inclusive growth for members 
of Parliament, government officials, academia, media, civil society, trade unions, 
and professional business associations; 
(vii)  carry out capacity development activities to increase policy makers’ and the 
business  community’s  capacity  to  address  inclusiveness,  and  identify,  invite, 
manage,  and  compensate  two  national  speakers  in  carrying  out  capacity 
development activities; 
(viii)  prepare  best  international  policy  practices  from  resource-rich  countries  on 
promoting inclusive growth; and 
(ix)  prepare a knowledge product on inclusive growth in Mongolia, including drivers 
of inequality (including attention to gender dimensions) and key policy challenges 
that need to be addressed in priority sectors. 
 
3.  Labor market expert (international, 2 person-months). The expert will preferably have 
at least 10 years of experience in labor market analysis. Expertise in procurement will be a plus. 
The expert will have at least a master’s degree in labor market economics, labor policy, or other 
relevant disciplines. The expert will 
(i)  analyze  labor  market  mechanisms  in  Mongolia  to  identify  weaknesses  in 
engaging the private sector and matching supply and demand;

Appendix 3  11 
(ii)  design,  implement,  monitor,  evaluate,  and  report  on  a  pilot  project  on 
decentralization  of  the  procurement  process  (in  line  with  the  amended 
procurement law); and 
(iii)  prepare capacity building materials for local government, small entrepreneurs, 
and local nongovernment organizations to support decentralized procurement, on 
a pilot basis, including addressing possible gendered barriers to participation. 
 
4.  Senior  social  scientist  and  policy  development  expert  (international,  3  person-
months). The expert will have preferably at least 10 years of experience in social policy, social 
protection,  or  other  relevant  disciplines.  The  expert  will  have  experience  in  design  and 
implementation  of  targeted  employment  programs  and  extensive  experience  in  monitoring 
results. The expert will have at least a master’s degree in social policy, social protection, or 
other relevant social sciences. The expert will 
(i)  design and implement a pilot project to increase the access to employment of 
poor urban and rural households identified through proxy means testing—this will 
include selection of the pilot site and study population, preparation of a study 
protocol,  identification  of  social  and  gender  issues,  and  description  of 
organizational matters; 
(ii)  design  and  implement  mechanisms  to  facilitate  a  focus  on  inclusive  growth 
strategies for employment among private sector stakeholders seeking to target 
the poor; and 
(iii)  monitor, evaluate, and report on the pilot activities—this will include development 
of monitoring and evaluation tools, reporting, and dissemination. 
 
5.  Social and economic policy development expert (national, 12 person-months). The 
national expert will assist the team leader in delivering the outputs of the technical assistance 
(TA), provide interpretation and translation services, and arrange meetings as required. The 
national  expert  will  have  at  least  10  years  of  experience  in  social  and  economic  policy 
development with at least a master’s degree in development economics, social policy, or other 
relevant disciplines. More specifically, the expert will 
(i)  assist  in  preparing  outreach  tools  to  disseminate  information  and  create 
awareness on inclusive growth; 
(ii)  assist in defining and developing monitoring and evaluation, and policy analysis 
capacity for inclusive growth of the Cabinet Office, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of 
Economic Development, and selected sector ministries (Ministry of Population 
Development and Social Protection, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Education and 
Science); 
(iii)  assist in developing capacity development tools for action on inclusive growth for 
members of Parliament, government officials, academia, media, civil society, 
trade unions, and professional business associations; and 
(iv)  assist in implementing capacity development activities to increase policy makers’ 
and the business community’s capacity to address inclusiveness. 
 
6.  Labor market expert (national, 6 person-months). The expert will have at least 10 years 
of experience in labor market analysis and experience in procurement. The expert will have at 
least a master’s degree in labor economics, social policy, or other relevant disciplines. Expertise 
in procurement will be a plus. The expert will 
(i)  assist  in  analyzing  labor  market  mechanisms  in  Mongolia  and  identify 
weaknesses in engaging private sector and matching supply and demand; and 
(ii)  assist in the development of the pilot project on provision of capacity building to 
small  entrepreneurs  and  local  nongovernment  organizations  to  support

decentralized procurement (included in the amended procurement law)—this will 
include development of tools, provision of capacity building, and development of 
monitoring and evaluation methodologies and techniques. 
 
7.  Social scientist and policy development expert (national, 6 person-months). The 
expert will assist in implementing a pilot project to increase the access to employment of poor 
urban and rural households identified through proxy means testing. The expert will have at least 
10 years of experience in social protection, development studies, or other relevant disciplines. 
The expert will have experience with project development and implementation, monitoring, and 
evaluation. The expert will 
(i)  assist in the design and implement a pilot project to increase the access to 
employment of poor urban and rural households identified through proxy means 
testing—this  will  include  selection  of  the  pilot  site  and  study  population, 
preparation of a study protocol, identification of social and gender issues, and 
description of organizational matters; 
(ii)  assist in the design and implement mechanisms to facilitate a focus on inclusive 
growth strategies for employment among private sector stakeholders seeking to 
target the poor; and 
(iii)  assist in monitoring, evaluating, and reporting on the pilot activities—this will 
include  development  of  monitoring  and  evaluation  tools,  reporting,  and 
dissemination formats. 
 
B.  Consultative Processes and Media Outreach 
 
8.  Public relations expert (national, 10 person-months). The expert will have at least 
10 years  of  experience  in  the  design  and  delivery  of  public  consultation  events,  and  the 
organization and design of debate and workshop formats. The expert will 
(i)  conduct  a  participatory  process  to  define  inclusive  growth  in  the  context  of 
Mongolia; 
(ii)  assist in carrying out two workshops with international participants on inclusive 
growth; 
(iii)  explain and conduct a consultative process (with attention to rural–urban and 
gender dimensions) on inclusive growth with inputs from the other consultants on 
the TA; and 
(iv)  develop reporting and monitoring tools and formats for the outputs. 
 
C.  Socioeconomic Surveys  
 
9.  Senior  socioeconomic  survey  expert  (national, 6 person-months). The expert will 
have at least 15 years of experience in survey design and implementation. The expert will plan, 
organize, implement, analyze, and report on pre- and post-surveys on capacity to develop 
policies on inclusive growth; and analyze the country context and stakeholder understanding on 
fair distribution of income and wealth. The analysis will also identify any important differences 
based on factors such as rural or urban residence, gender, and age. 
 
10.  Administrative and technical coordinator (national, 24 person-months). The TA will 
recruit an administrative and technical coordinator on an individual basis. The coordinator will 
have at least 3 years of project administration and coordination experience. The coordinator will  
(i)  ensure the consulting firm submits draft semiannual and annual work plans to the
